sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying inductor
message_1: A circular loop of radius 10 cm carries a current of 2 A. Determine the magnetic field at the center of the loop due to this current.
message_2:
To determine the magnetic field at the center of the loop due to the current, we can use the formula for the magnetic field produced by a circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * R)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, and R is the radius of the loop.

Given the radius R = 10 cm = 0.1 m and the current I = 2 A, we can now calculate the magnetic field at the center of the loop:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A) / (2 * 0.1 m)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm) / 0.2 m

B = 4π × 10^(-6) T

The magnetic field at the center of the loop due to the current is approximately 4π × 10^(-6) T or 12.57 × 10^(-6) T (12.57 µT).
